title: You’ll need a £1million saved if you want a good retirement
text:

How do you picture your life after work?

If it's relaxing on the beach, eating nice food, driving a decent car and budgeting £50 a present for other people's birthdays then you might be in for a shock.

A new report from the Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association has worked out exactly what a comfortable retirement will cost people.

The idea is that if people can visualise what they want their life to be like, then they also know how much they need to save now to achieve it.

And the bad news is that a "comfortable" retirement will cost couples £45,000 a year on top of a full state pension, while singletons will need £30,000 a year to afford it.

To have enough saved to afford that when your not working means pension pots with £1million in them for a couple or £710,000 if both have full state pensions.

Nigel Peaple from the PLSA, said: “Goal setting can help people plan and a series of simple standards could transform pensions engagement."

He added: “The 5-a-day campaign did a lot to change perceptions about healthy eating. We hope the Retirement Living Standards will transform the way people think about what money they might need for their retirement."

The new Retirement Living Standards report breaks people's life after work into three categories - minimum, moderate and comfortable - then worked out the cost of living them.

The minimum lifestyle covers your essential bills plus some fun - you could holiday in the UK, eat out about once a month and do some "affordable" leisure activities about twice a week. It budgets £460 a year for clothes and shoes.

To reach that level you need £10,200 a year for a single person or £15,700 for a couple.

Given the state pension comes in at £8,767.20 a year - your standard workplace pension should cover you - although If you live in London, you'll need a little extra because of the higher cost of living.

(Image: Getty)

The moderate lifestyle includes the costs of owning and running a car (replaced every 10 years), as well as tripling the amount you can spend on birthday and Christmas presents and teo overseas holidays a year. It costs £20,200 a year for singles and £29,100 for couples. But to get to this level you'll need to put more work into your savings now.

At the comfortable level you get a much better quality of life - your weekly food budget is £56, there is money to replace your car every 5 years, pay for beauty treatments and three overseas holidays are included. You also get to spend up to £1,500 a year on clothes and food and can splash £50 a present on friends and relatives.

It also costs the most, coming in at £33,000 a year for singles and £47,500 for couples.

Jackie Spencer from the Money and Pensions Service said: “Saving for something is easier to do when you can visualise what you’re working towards, which is why people are often more motivated to save for short-term goals like holidays and new cars than they are for their retirement.

“The new Retirement Living Standards are a great way of offering savers some practical examples of what they can expect from their lives when they stop working.”

description: If you'd like a retirement where you can still afford three foreign holidays a year sand to be able foo replace your car every five years you need to have saved an awful lot of cash first
